content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the payoff structure, it seems that the opponent is always better off when I choose B, as they get 42$ while I only get 0$ if we both pick R. However, if we both consistently choose B, they will earn 12$ each round, and I will too, which amounts to a total of 900$ for them over 75 rounds.

On the other hand, if I choose R and my opponent chooses B in every round, they will earn 3150$, while I only get 75*45 = 3375$. That's a difference of 2100$ between us.

Now, let's consider the possibility that my opponent is not as rational or consistent as assumed. If I pick R in the first round and they don't reciprocate (pick B), I could switch to picking B from then on to earn at least 900$. This strategy would allow me to secure some earnings, although it means I will never reach the maximum potential payoff of 3375$ if my opponent starts being rational.

Given these considerations and understanding that the game is played anonymously, I might choose R in the first round to take advantage of any potential inconsistency or irrationality on the part of my opponent. However, this is a risky strategy as it could result in earning less overall if the opponent turns out to be rational and responds with B consistently.

So, if I were playing this game, I would choose R as my initial move, but I would also keep an open mind for switching strategies depending on how my opponent behaves throughout the rounds.

{R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

After my first move resulted in a 0$ payoff, I might start thinking that my opponent is more rational than initially assumed and may stick to their strategy of choosing B when I pick R. In this case, switching strategies at this point could lead to even lower earnings for me as I would consistently get 0$.

Since the goal of maximizing earnings over multiple rounds remains, I will switch my strategy in the next round and choose B. This way, if my opponent continues with their choice of B, I can earn 12$ per round, which is more than the 0$ I currently get by sticking to R. So, if I were playing the next round, I would choose B as my move.
